none: Translated title: Fāʼidah on a woman to be loved by a man
Part of the Maktaba grant project (Local Note)
In Arabic in Maghrebi style script and Hausa in ajami. (Language Note)
Arabic Manuscripts from West Africa--The ‘Umar Falke Collection

A fāʾida (a genre of text offering specific recipes, practices, or actions that promise the user assistance in times of need) from northern Nigeria dating from the late nineteenth or early twentieth centuries. The purpose of this fāʼida is to grant a woman the love of a man, so that he loves her as the Prophet Muḥammad loved his wife Aʾisha.

The images on this web site are from material in the collections of the Melville J. Herskovits Library of African Studies at Northwestern University Libraries, are provided for use by its students, faculty and staff, and by other researchers visiting this site, for research consultation and scholarly purposes only. Homepage at Northwestern University Libraries Digital Collections

This rare collection of manuscripts dates back to the 19th and 20th centuries and come from mainly northern Nigeria (Kano in particular) but also includes items from Ghana, Senegal and Mali. Mostly handwritten in Arabic and Ajami scripts, these manuscripts cover a wide range of subjects from Arabic grammar, history, theology, law and astronomy to name a few, with particular strength in Tijâniyya Sufi order and Hausa poetry.   Comprised of 5,000 items, the manuscripts are split across four separate collections and serve as an excellent example of West African literacy in Arabic:  The 'Umar Falke Collection, The John Paden Collection, The John Hunwick Collection, The University of Ghana Collection

body.value:
*Translated by Paul Naylor* 



In the name of God, the Most Gracious the Most Merciful. Whoever wants to grant a woman the love of a man, write \[the following formula\] and \[give it\] to drink, along with the name of the woman. He will not be able to eat, to sit, or to sleep until he sees you, by the will of God the most high. \[The formula is:\]

> Oh God, love like the love Muḥammad had for ʿAʾisha; Oh God, love like the love ʿAlī had for Fatima; Oh God, love like the love a believer has for Paradise; Oh God, love like the love an unbeliever has for alcohol; Oh God, love like the love a powerful Sultan has for attention; Oh God, love like the love of a Sultan.

This is a remedy for anyone who wants to get married.[^1]

[^1]: This phrase is in Hausa: *Maganin na mai son aure*."

"بسم الله الرحمن الرحيم  

فائدة ومن أراد المرأة محبة 

الرجل تكتب وتشرب مع اسم المر 

أة لاكر ولا تجلس ولا نوم حتى يراك  

بإذن الله تقدر اللهم محبة 

كما محبة كما محمد عند عائشة  

اللهم محبة كما محبة علي عند فا 

طمة اللهم محبة كما محبة المؤمن 

عند الجنة اللهم محبة كما 

محبة الكافر عند الخمر اللهم محبة كما 

محبة السلطان المير عند النظر اللهم 

محبة كما محبة السلطان 

صاغني نوصرضوا "
